Subject: Re: [neat] HyperNEAT C++ Crossover
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=EPUovdA7eqfLqV8w0UNa4tlUFZEE7izuVhqDQpw6KrQ-wBIjmW1D
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Thanks to both of you for looking into the issue.

I noticed that the current code (with the random choice line inside the loop
as Jason and I discussed) chooses each link at random from either parent in
proportion to the parent's fitness. Is that how the updated code will work
too?

If so, it strikes me that might really slice up building blocks. To take
P-NEAT, which is easier to think about, if one neural module existed in a
region of the substrate, and a different neural module existed in the same
region in a parent, instead of possibly grabbing the whole module from one
parent and sticking it in a new genetic background, crossover would take a
few links from the modules of each of the parents and see if they work
together. 

To use a nice metaphor Ken has used before, in crossover you want to swap a
hand for a hand instead of take a hand and put it where an ear belongs. This
system is at least swapping parts of hands for parts of hands, but it
(almost) never allows an *entire* hand to be placed on a new body. Instead,
it sees if taking x% of phenotypic slices from one hand works in combination
with 100-x% of phenotypic slices from the other hand.

I hope that makes sense.

This is very similar to the question in GAs of using uniform (swapping
slices of hands) vs. one- or two-point crossover (potentially swapping
entire hands). 

A few questions
1) does canonical NEAT use the uniform version of crossover or something
like two-point crossover?
2) does the version of HyperNEAT you are about to release use uniform or
two-point?
3) if the answer to 1 is 'uniform', has anyone ever looked at trying
something like two-point?




Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Thu, 13 Nov 2008 00:25:50 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] HyperNEAT C++ Crossover
> 
> Jason and I have been checking the debugged crossover operator by
> rerunning experiments and it appears that (as expected) in aggregate
> results are not altered in any significant way.  Jason plans to
> release a revised version of HyperNEAT C++ with the fix in the next
> few days after some more careful checking to make sure it's working as
> it should.  
> 
> Jeff, thanks very much for bringing the crossover bug to our
> attention.  The good news is it should not significantly affect major
> conclusions from prior experimental results.
> 
> ken
>
